para.emphasis: This Chapter describes classes, objects, methods, attributes and object literals and describes the class relationship between JavaFX Script classes and Java classes.

sect1.title: Calling Java Objects
sect1.para: JavaFX Script programs can import Java classes, create new Java objects, call methods on objects, and implement Java interfaces.

sect1.title: Classes and Objects
sect1.para: JavaFX Script syntax for specifying a class is the class keyword followed by the class name, optionally the extends keyword, and a comma separated list of the names of base classes, an open curly brace, a list of attributes, functions, and operations that each end in a semicolon, and a closing curly brace.

You can declare class attributes using the attribute keyword; followed by the attribute's name; a colon; the attribute's type; and optionally, a cardinality specification (? meaning optional, * meaning zero or more, or + meaning one or more), and an optional inverse clause specifying a bidirectional relationship to another attribute in the class of the attributes' type, and terminated with a semicolon.
sect1.programlisting: attribute AttributeName : AttributeType Cardinality inverse ClassName.InverseAttributeName;
sect1.para: If the inverse clause is present, the interpreter automatically performs updates (insert, delete or replace depending on the kind of update and cardinalities of the attributes) on the inverse attribute whenever the attribute's value is modified.

Multi-valued attributes (i.e. those declared with the * or + cardinality specifiers) are represented as arrays. You can access them using the [] operator and update them using the insert and delete operators.
Unlike Java methods, the bodies all JavaFX Script member operations and member functions are defined outside of the class declaration:
Parameter and return types are required in the declaration of operations and functions in the class declaration but may be omitted in their definitions.

sect2.title: Object Literals
sect2.para: JavaFX Script objects may be allocated using a declarative syntax consisting of the name of the class followed by a curly brace delimited list of attribute initializers. Each initializer consists of the attribute name followed by a colon, followed by an expression which defines its value (but see below regarding JavaFX Script's support for incremental evaluation in this context).
